Developers might want to surface UIs for

terminal purposes to send the sequence ESC-Letter, instead of the macOS specific character and
means that when mouse-aware applications are running, they hijack the normal selection process.

abstract.text: TerminalView provides an AppKit front-end to the
termininal emulator.
It is up to a subclass to either wire the terminal emulator to a remote terminal
via some socket, to an application that wants to run with terminal emulation, or
wiring this up to a pseudo-terminal.
This method is invoked when the terminal needs to set the title for the window,
a UI toolkit would react by setting the terminal title in the window or any other
user visible element.
Sends data to the terminal emulator for interpretation, this can be invoked from a background thread
Invoked when the user has long-pressed and then clicked “Select”
Controls the color for the caret
Gets a value indicating the relative position of the terminal viewport
This method should return
if operations that can read the buffer back should be allowed,
otherwise, return false.   This is useful to run some applications that attempt to checksum the
contents of the screen (unit tests)
This method is invoked when the terminal needs to set the title for the minimized icon,
a UI toolkit would react by setting the terminal title in the icon or any other
user visible element
Callback - the window was scrolled, new yDisplay passed
The default implementation does nothing.
The font to use to render the terminal
is an AppKit NSView that can be used to host a local process
the process is launched inside a pseudo-terminal.
SwiftTerm is a VT100/Xterm terminal emulator library for Swift applications that
can be embedded into macOS, iOS applications, text-based, headless applications
or other custom scenarios.
Invoked to request that the cursor be shown
Invoked to request that the cursor be shown
Scrolls the content of the terminal one page up
This method is invoked when the buffer changes from Normal to Alternate, or Alternate to Normal
The default implementation does nothing.
TerminalView provides an AppKit front-end to the
termininal emulator.
It is up to a subclass to either wire the terminal emulator to a remote terminal
via some socket, to an application that wants to run with terminal emulation, or
wiring this up to a pseudo-terminal.
Sets the various fonts to be used by the terminal to render text, their size is ignored
This vaiable controls whether mouse events are sent to the application running under the
terminal if it has requested the data.   This poses a problem for selection, so users
need a way of toggling this behavior.
This will set the native foreground color to the specified native color (UIColor or NSColor)
and will have this reflected into the underlying’s terminal
and
It looks like sending carriage return works on Unix and Windows remote hosts, so add that, but keeping a public
property in case someone needs the return key to send different sequences.
Sends the byte data to the client connected to the terminal (in terminal emulation
documentation, this is the “host”)
Sends the specified string encoded at utf8 to the program running under the terminal emulator
The font to use to render the terminal, this attempts to derive the bold, italic and italic/bold variants from
the original font, using the iOS UIFontDescriptor APIs.   For full control use the
API instead
Controls the color for the caret
Sends the specified array of bytes to the program running under the terminal emulator
If set, this turns Option-letter keystrokes into an escape + keystroke combination
which is convenient when you are an Emacs user for example.   But this means that
international input using the option key is not easy to enter.
This will set the native foreground color to the specified native color (UIColor or NSColor)
and will have this reflected into the underlying’s terminal

Sends the specified slice of byte arrays to the program running under the terminal emulator
Triggers a resize of the underlying terminal to the desired columsn and rows
Sets the color for the cursor block, and the text when it is under that cursor in block mode

The terminal delegate is a protocol that must be implemented by a class
that would provide a user interface for the terminal, and it is used by the
to notify of important changes on the underlying terminal
This flag is automatically set to true after the initializer is called, if running on a system older than BigSur.
Starting with BigSur any screen updates will invoke the draw() method with the whole region, regardless
of how much changed.   Setting this to true, will disable this OS behavior, setting it to false, will keep
the original BigSur behavior to redraw the whole region.
The frame used by the caretView
Given the current set of columns and rows returns a frame that would host this control.
Scrolls the content of the terminal one page down
You can set this property to a UIView to be your input accessory, by default

Controls the color for the text in the caret when using a block cursor, if not set
the cursor will render with the foreground color
This method is invoked when the client application (iTerm2) has issued a OSC 1337 and
SwiftTerm did not handle a handler for it.
Installs the new colors as the default colors and recomputes the
current and ansi palette.   This installs both the colors into the terminal
engine and updates the UI accordingly.
Controls the color for the text in the caret when using a block cursor, if not set
the cursor will render with the foreground color
Set to true if the selection is active, false otherwise
Callback a newline was generated
The default implementation does nothing.
Returns the thumb size in proportion to the visible content of the entire content, alternate buffers are not scrollable, so this returns 0
This controls whether the backspace should send ^? or ^H, the default is ^?
Should raise the bell
The default implementation does nothing.

These are various commands that are sent by the client.  They are rare,
and if you do not know what to return, just return nil, the terminal
will return a suitable value.
